header.title: LIBER 60 THERE GOES GALAHAD
authors: The International College of Martinists Incorporated

central_thesis: This Liber outlines a comprehensive system of spiritual advancement for the mystical enlightenment of man, integrating Rosicrucian, Martinist, and Masonic traditions through a Christian Kabbalistic interpretation of creation, fall, redemption, and the pursuit of spiritual wholeness, exemplified by the Galahad quest and the esoteric work within Masonic degrees.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Esoteric Tradition and The Temple: The Rosicrucians and The Rose Croix
structure_content.summary: This section introduces Rosicrucianism as a complex mystical Christian tradition of the 17th century, distinct from later Rose-Croix Freemasonry. It details their historical context as adversaries of the Catholic Church, their leanings towards Protestantism, and their core goals of healing, anonymous help, political and religious reform towards a universal state and pristine Christianity, and the reintegration of man and nature. Key texts for studying Rosicrucian history are also recommended.

The legendary founder, Christian Rosenkreutz, is presented not as a historical figure but a symbolic name, derived from Hebrew 'rosah koroz' meaning 'Herald of the Secret,' signifying a vehicle of the angel Keraziel. The Rosicrucians utilized traditional occult knowledge (alchemy, magic, theurgy, astrology) and integrated Christian Gnosis with Jewish Kabbalah, functioning as Christian Kabbalists. A particular branch, 'Rosy-Cross of the East' (Knights of St. John the Evangelist), based in Thessalonica, and its filiation through Papus, is also described.

This part explains the Rosicrucian understanding of 'creative prayer' as an efficient method based on Cornelius Agrippa's occult rule. Efficacy is achieved by linking prayer to its celestial archetype or historical event, such as the crossing of the Red Sea for safe maritime travel. The method involves the operant being devoid of profane attire, wearing specific ritual garments (white alb, cordelier, consecrated sandals), and operating before an altar adorned with golden silk, an open Gospel of St. John, and a beeswax candle.

The core doctrine, shared with Martinism and Christian Kabbalists, describes God as an infinitely perfect, omnipotent, and eternal Essential Being. Creation occurs in cycles (Manvantara and Pralaya), where beings, through their volition, become fixed in goodness (angels) or evil (demons) for subsequent creations ('aeons'). The concept of 'Adam' is defined as a collective egregore, not a carnal being, whose 'Fall' led to spiritual degradation and materialization.

structure_content.chapter_title: Concerning the Preexistence of Souls, Temptation and Fall, Redemption, and Apocatastasis
structure_content.summary: This section elaborates on the preexistence of souls, the Fall of Man as a spiritual degradation, and the necessity of Christ's incarnation for redemption. The process of 'Apocatastasis,' or final reintegration, is presented as the ultimate resolution, where all souls are eventually returned to their original perfect state, implying no eternal hell. This redemption extends to all Nature, initiated by Christ and continued by Man.

The universal symbolism of the Cross and the Rose is analyzed. The Cross represents the insertion of the microcosm (man) within the macrocosm, encompassing the four cardinal points, alchemical elements, and active/passive principles. The Rose is a yonic symbol associated with generation, spiritual unfoldment, purity, and the blood of Christ (red rose), signifying the human heart, love, and compassion. Meditation on these symbols is said to profoundly affect inner lives, connecting to the Rosicrucian symbol of a crucified rose.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Quest of the Holy Grail: Galahad
structure_content.summary: The Holy Grail is presented as a symbol of spiritual wholeness, linked to ancient sacred tables and Galahad's role in its achievement on Pentecost. Galahad, though sometimes seen as a 'cardboard' character due to his flawless goodness, is ultimately understood as the embodiment of humanity as a perfect vessel for Divine light, achieving the Grail through utter simplicity and directness in his spiritual quest. His journey signifies the highest level of inner quest beyond fragmented reality.

This chapter details the esoteric significance of Masonic Deacons, particularly the Senior Deacon, within the 'Second Order.' Kabbalistically, they align with Geburah and Chesed. The Senior Deacon, likened to Mercury, vitalizes lodge work, guides the Neofite to 'Light' and esoterism, and symbolizes the 'faithful friend' in life. However, ultimate 'raising' (advancement) requires the Neofite's own stamina and decisions, as the Senior Deacon's guidance extends only 'as far as the Law of Limitations permits.'

The three Masonic degrees (Enterd Apprentice, Fellow-Craft, Master Mason) are correlated with human consciousness (Normal, Sub-Conscious, Super-Conscious) and aspects of Man (Body, Soul, Spirit). The Fellow-Craft Degree specifically relates to the 'Soul of Man' (etheric substance), intellectual nature, and the Sub-Consciousness. It teaches equilibrium, balance, and the 'freeing of emotionalism' from suppression. Masonic symbols like the Cable Tow (Threefold Body), Compasses/Square (Spirit/Matter), and mystic numbers (3, 5, 7, 9) are explained as tools for understanding Man's spiritual journey and inner refinement.

key_concepts.definition: Profound, mystical Christians who, as adversaries of the Catholic Church, leaned towards Protestantism. They utilized traditional occult forms (alchemy, magic, theurgy, astrology) and their doctrine combined Christian Gnosis with Jewish Kabbalah, acting as Christian Kabbalists. Their goals included healing, anonymous help, political/religious reform towards a universal state and pristine Christianity, and reintegrating man and nature.

A symbolic name, not historical, derived from Hebrew 'rosah koroz' ('Herald of the Secret'), signifying a vehicle for the angel Keraziel and the function of communicating the 'Secret' (God Himself) from esoteric writings.

key_concepts.term: Rosy-Cross of the East (Knights of St. John the Evangelist)
key_concepts.definition: A particular branch of Rosicrucians reorganized around 1750-1780 with a center in Thessalonica. Papus received its unique filiation. Initiation involves the 'Ordination of Eques A Sancti Joannis Evangelistae' and wearing a black cloak with white lining.

An efficient prayer method based on Cornelius Agrippa's occult rule, where Holy Scripture is seen as rooted in the 'archetypal world.' It requires linking prayer to a celestial archetype or historical event (e.g., Red Sea crossing for maritime safety) and is performed by an operant devoid of profane clothing, wearing a white alb, cordelier, consecrated sandals, with an uncovered head, before an altar with specific items.
Not a carnal being, but a collectivity or egregore. The 'first Man' was an egregore, and its central spirit was the 'true Adam.' Souls preexisted within this context.

The doctrine of final reintegration, asserting that there is no eternal hell, only temporary 'sojourns.' All souls are ultimately perfected and reintegrated into their original state, thus justifying a universal redemption.

Universal profound symbols. The Cross represents the microcosm's insertion into the macrocosm, four cardinal points, alchemical elements, and active/passive principles. The Rose symbolizes generation, spiritual unfoldment, purity, passion (red rose for Christ's blood/suffering), and the spiritual gold within human nature (golden heart), emblematic of love and compassion. Their combination is central to Rosicrucian identity.

The central hero of later Grail stories, embodying pure, faultless goodness. He is presented as a 'perfect vessel for the Divine light' whose directness and simplicity allow him to achieve the Holy Grail, representing humanity's ultimate spiritual potential and enlightenment.

A key figure in Masonic lodges, representing the 'Second Order' (Kabbalistically, Geburah/Chesed). Esoterically, he is the 'actinic property' of the Ray, vitalizing lodge work, guiding the Neofite to 'Light' and esoterism. He symbolizes a faithful friend, but the Neofite's ultimate 'raising' to mastery depends on personal will and stamina.

This degree relates to the 'Soul of Man,' seen as etheric substance derived from the threefold body (physical, etheric, astral). It addresses man's intellectual nature and the Sub-Consciousness, teaching equilibrium, balance, and the 'freeing of emotionalism' (one point of the Compasses freed) to cultivate spiritual faculties and achieve greater perception.

A phase of human consciousness superior and more potent than Normal consciousness. It receives information from Normal consciousness and holds thoughts tenaciously, acting as the root of faith, hope, belief, intuition, and prescience. Its development is crucial for spiritual perception.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a multi-layered path for spiritual advancement, integrating specific ritual practices, symbolic meditation, and a conceptual framework for inner work. It leverages the historical and esoteric interpretations of Rosicrucianism, Martinism, and Freemasonry, presenting Masonic degrees not merely as ceremonies but as stages of consciousness development and practical instruction in the 'Soul of Man.' The emphasis is on disciplined inner transformation to achieve reintegration and mystical enlightenment.
tools: Gospel of St. John: Used in Creative Prayer as a 'condenser of the presence of the Christ.'
Candlestick with beeswax candle: Utilized in Creative Prayer.
White alb, cordelier, consecrated sandals: Prescribed ritual attire for Creative Prayer.
Altar cloth of golden silk: Used to adorn the altar during Creative Prayer.
Black cloak with white lining: Specific regalia for the 'Rosy-Cross of the East' initiation.
The Grail, The Rose, The Cross: Powerful symbols used for deep meditation to effect inner spiritual transformation.
Masonic Compasses and Square: Representing Spirit and Matter, used in the Fellow-Craft degree to symbolize the balancing of polarities and freeing of emotionalism.
rituals: Creative Prayer: A specific ceremonial practice involving particular attire (white alb, cordelier, consecrated sandals), an uncovered head, and an altar setup with a golden silk cloth, an open Gospel of St. John, and a beeswax candle. This is performed by linking the prayer to celestial archetypes for enhanced efficacy.
Ordination of Eques A Sancti Joannis Evangelistae: An initiatic ritual within the 'Rosy-Cross of the East' Order, which includes specific regalia like a black cloak with a white lining.

Masonic Fellow-Craft Degree Work: Operative rituals guided by the Senior Deacon to bring the Neofite to 'Light,' involving structured instruction and symbolic actions aimed at developing the 'Soul of Man' and balancing emotional and intellectual polarities (symbolized by freeing one point of the Compasses).

relevant_quotes.text: The International College of Martinists Incorporated, is a non-profit institution existing for the purpose of disseminating information on the Traditional Esoteric Arcana.

There were three tables associated with the Grail: the Table of the Last Supper, the table at which the guardians of the cup first sat, and the Round Table or King Arthur and his knights. According to tradition, ail three were round, and those who sat at them were dedicated to the seeking of spiritual wholeness.

The Rosicrucians of the 17th century were profound, mystical Christians. They were adversaries of the Catholic Church of that time because of its intolerant attitude. The Rosicrucians therefore tended more towards the Protestant trend, in spite of the anti-esoteric posture of the latter.

In order to realize their great plan, which would require many centuries, the Rosicrucians utilized all the traditional occult forms of knowledge: alchemy, magic, theurgy, astrology, etc.. Their doctrine was a combination of the Christian Gnosis and the Jewish Kabalah. They were, in reality, Christian Kabalists.

The Rosicrucians knew of the invaluable effects of prayer. They knew that creative prayers laid on the occult rule mentioned by Cornelius Agrippa in his famous Occult Philosophy which states that Holy Scripture is a compilation of "historical facts" that have their roots in the "archetypal world."

God, as an Essential Being, existing by Himself and in Himself, without need or variation, infinitely good, infinitely wise, because He is infinitely perfect and All-Powerful. By being omnipotent and eternal, His Power was necessarily exercised over eternity and all beings.

The name Adam does not refer to a carnal being but a collectivity. When we say "Adam" it is as if we were saying "the army". The first Man was an egregore, and it is the central spirit of this egregore who was the true Adam.
Let us replace "pearls" by "souls", "necklace" by "Total Man" and the "owner" by "God", then the problem of final restitution is resolved, and the apocatastasis is justified.

The Rose and the Cross are very profound symbols in the sense that if we meditate or even think about them, they affect us deeply. Like the symbol of the Grail, regular meditation on the Rose and the Cross can have very strong effects on our inner lives.

Now, one difficulty with the character of Galahad, which makes him appear "cardboard" to Cavendish, is that he is utterly simple and direct in his movement, through all the adventures, towards his goal. He has no faults, he is in fact a truly Good man, so he is called "The Good Knight," and SO he seems impossibly strange to us â€“ as strange, maybe, as a visitor from another planet! Yet is not the simplicity of goodness what is in fact proper to humanity? Indeed Galahad entirely expresses the idea, Kabalistic if you will, of humanity as a perfect vessel for the Divine light.

The Senior Deacon, esoterically, may be likened to the actinic property and potency of hat Ray. His work it is, that vitalizes the general floor work of the Lodge and, in association with the Master, it is he who actively assists in bringing the Neofite to Light and then makes that Light clear and lucid by his subsequent interlocutions.

The Fellow-Craft Degree relates to the Soul of Man. Soul is a phase of etheric substance that is derived or developt as a definite pabulum from the physical body or rather, the threefold body of Man, physical, etheric and astral.
In the Fellow-Craft Degree, one point of the Compasses is freed. This esoterically, is the point of emotionalism, which the philosofy of the world has taught and still largely teaches us to suppress.

critical_analysis.relevance: This Liber serves as an essential instructional text for initiates within the International College of Martinists, providing a syncretic framework that unifies Rosicrucian, Martinist, and Masonic traditions under a Christian Kabbalistic lens. Its relevance lies in offering a detailed esoteric cosmology (creation, fall, redemption, apocatastasis) and delineating the inner spiritual work necessary for 'mystical enlightenment.' It contextualizes the symbolic language and practices of these traditions, emphasizing the active, operative side of esoteric study for personal transformation.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is initiated members of 'THE INTERNATIONAL COLLEGE OF MARTINISTS INCORPORATED,' specifically those progressing through the 'PLANE III LIBER 60 GRADE: COMPANION' to the 'FIFTH DEGREE.' The text is designed for 'personal and private study' by those with a foundational understanding of esoteric concepts, providing a curriculum for advanced spiritual development.
